oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Hallmarks of Country Music - Bob Wills
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of an interview of Bob Wills (musician). The interview is hosted by Andy Jackson (army solider) for the Hallmarks of Country Music segment. The tape was recorded on an unidentified date.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Bob Wills; Rick Phillips; Andy Jackson
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Hallmarks tune [featuring Rick Phillips introduction voiceover] ([Unidentified]) -- (00:53) Army National Guard commercial spot hosted by an unidentified host -- (01:55) Bob Wills introduces himself atop of a an unidentified tune -- (03:18) Army R.O.T.C. commercial spot hosted by an unidentified host -- (03:49) Andy Jackson discusses Wills' birth (04:23) Fat Boy Rag (Bob Wills) -- (07:10) Jackson recalls Wills' early years and a bet that set Wills' career into motion -- (08:36) John Wills discusses how the family worked on a cotton farm, and how Bob Wills desired a different life -- (10:23) Jackson describes how Wills worked smaller shows before moving home -- (11:35) Guitar Boogie (Bob Wills) -- (14:09) Jackson describes Wills initial work as a professional touring musician -- (15:16) Roly Poly (Bob Wills) -- (17:40) Army Community Service commercial spot hosted by an unidentified host -- (18:39) Jackson introduces ""Texas Playboy Rag"" -- (18:53) Texas Playboy Rag (Bob Wills and His Texas Playboys) -- (21:34) Jackson reflects on McAuliffe, and McAuliffe reflects on how Wills had hired him as a member in his band -- (24:43) Jackson introduces ""Steel Guitar Rag"" -- (24:56) Steel Guitar Rag (Bob Wills) -- (27:33) Jackson reflects on how Wills began working for himself -- (28:09) Wills reflects on his first dance job -- (29:40) Wills discusses a number of his recording sessions -- (31:27) Jackson introduces Wills to reflect on how Take Me Back to Tulsa changed his life -- (33:13) Take Me Back to Tulsa (Bob Wills) -- (35:53) Foreign drug policy commercial spot hosted by an unidentified host -- (36:46) Phillips discusses how the military used Wills for a propaganda tool -- (38:13) The San Antonio Rose (Bob Wills) -- (40:48) The New San Antonio Rose (Bob Wills) -- (43:26) Jackson and McAuliffe reflect on Wills' perfectionist styling -- (45:01) Unidentified Fiddle tune [featuring Wills and Phillips voiceover] ([Unidentified]) -- (47:58) Jackson continues to praise Wills legacy -- (48:18) E. P. M. S. military radio spot hosted by an unidentified host -- (49:04) Jackson reflects on how Wills had passed away -- (50:54) Faded Love (Bob Wills) -- (52:39) Hallmarks outro tune [featuring Phillips outro voiceover] ([Unidentified])
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:isPartOf: Insert is of program information. The insert features time stamps.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Jackson, Andy; Phillips, Rick; Wills, Bob, 1905-1975;
